THOMAS MCNAY

Why Don't the Girls Propose?
Why don't the girls propose, Papa?
Why don't the girls propose?
Each one seems coming to the point,
And then away she goes.
They're not quite so sure this year,
As they used to be last year.
They flirt quite in a manly way,
But oh, they won't propose.

I've read the latest fashions,
And seen the latest fashions,
And danced the same old dance,
With a quite commonplace skill;
I am sure that I could know
A thing or two about them,
And I seem to understand them,
But they won't—what do you propose?

That most remarkable of stories,
That most remarkable of stories,
That most remarkable of stories,
About making dresses,
I have studied with attention,
Till my head begins to spin.
That may be, may not attract them,
Yet still they seem, you see, one.

I've practiced charming innocence,
And creeping at the play;
And playing at the game,
In a most engaging way;
For I stand hard by knicks and hips,
And laugh at all the tricks they play.
And smiled with sweet pretension,
But they will not propose.

It's really very hard, Papa—there's none for me to choose from—there's nothing to catch my eye.
The water is warm and faint; but while I propose every art,
I'm afraid they'll laugh at me.
Why do the girls propose, Papa?
Why do the girls propose?

It is now announced that the English and American Governments are to unite in common cause and concerted action against dynamite conspiracies and assassins. This is as it should be. Governments should combine to put an end to any movement tending to undermine the basis of peace and safety and malicious destruction of life and property. It has been very discreditable to the American authorities for years and years, and the honest and brave men have been allowed to go on with impunity in their open band of organizations expressly designed to destroy the public property and endanger the lives of thousands of innocent citizens as well as to collect large sums of money for that express purpose. In few other countries would anything so dangerous and so destructive have been so long permitted.

Tuesday May 1. Profound consternation through the discovery of two persons dynamite cartridges with five pounds of dynamite each. The Imperial Munitions Office at the parliament buildings, they were found by a man named Thomas Wilson. A thorough search revealed two more approaching the speakers chamber, these cartridges were found by Mr. Wilson and have been placed in police custody pending discovery. There is great excitement throughout the present city. The cartridges are about six inches long by one and a half in diameter, and contain a charge of dynamite. It was evidently kept to keep moisture out. If the cartridges found would have been enough to blow up the whole city.
Portage la Prairie, May 1. John Boulter, of this town, cleared for the States after examining his chests containing dynamite cartridges. The particulars of the case are very sad.
Havana, Cuba, May 1. A terrible explosion killed 21 persons, 74, 160,000 cartridges and 200 pounds of powder and a barrel of dynamite blown up. Havana badly shaken up.

San Francisco, April 20.—The six day contest, the bicycle versus the horse, was finished today. Mr. Anderson had a number of followers who thought Mr. Armande rode alternately on bicycles. The two latter made 1675 miles, the best record ever made by any two men. Portland, Ore., April 19.—Andrew Higgins, a wealthy farmer near Portland, was killed by a falling tree. Mrs. Knott, who staggered out of a short distance from the house and buried it, was severely injured. She was found foraging in the woods. Knott supposed that Higgins had been killed in the house. A vigilance committee is looking into his death.

THE DUDE.
How they came to let a dude stay in Texas.
"Talk about yer deeds," said a Texan stockman on the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy train last night, "a little the dude don't live up to what he's a fellow that says he's a dude ought to be able to do."
"He don't stay in Texas long, I guess, and all little things like that."
"Yes, he's there now."
"I thought they wouldn't let a dude live in Texas, didn't I?"
"Well, I'll tell you how it was we come ter let him stay. He come down here on the train as a regular dude, but he had a lot of money in his pockets and a lot of clothes on his back."
"He's got a lot of money in his pockets and a lot of clothes on his back."

MOOSE JAW
From the Moose Jaw Tribune, April 18.
Great fishing in the creek.
The Moose Jaw River and Thunder Creek have once more attained respectability, thanks to the efforts of the local government.
Numerous Temperance Clubs have been organized throughout the province, with the object of promoting temperance among the citizens.
The C. E. R. R. has obtained a new locomotive for the efficient work at their new well at Regina.
An attractive programme was presented at the annual Band Concert and Banquet, to augment the entertainment offered.
The entertainment was a complete success and reflects credit on those who undertook to be responsible for it.

REGINA
From the Leader, April 19.
As it has been stated that we have no rain in Regina, excepting in June, we are obliged to rely upon the heavy rain which fell yesterday, to prove that this statement is utterly untrue.
The C. E. R. R. has obtained a new locomotive for the efficient work at their new well at Regina.
An attractive programme was presented at the annual Band Concert and Banquet, to augment the entertainment offered.
The entertainment was a complete success and reflects credit on those who undertook to be responsible for it.

MANITOBA.
From the Winnipeg Free Press, April 20.
The Manitoba Government is urging up.
The Sons of Temperance now number five hundred members.
There is much talk of a company being formed in the city of Winnipeg, and it is expected that this can be found within the limits of the province.
It is understood that no store suitable for building purposes can be found east or west, and it is very likely that our quarters will be started up again before long.

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE.
From the Evening Telegram, April 21.
Beautiful weather.
Fishing and shooting will commence in a few days.
W. Pratt sold 3,000 bushels of wheat when this week.
Two shipments arrived here this week, one to different points along the M. & N. W. Ry.
The junior branch of the Y. M. C. A. has organized an infantry company in connection with their association.

WINNIPEG.
From the Telegram, April 22.
The new mining regulations of the Dominion Government are causing great dissatisfaction among practical miners at Silver City.
Calgary has been erected into an outport custom and a warehousing port, and placed under the control of the coldest winter of Winnipeg.
The adherents of the Church of England in Calgary have resolved to organize a church in that town.
Subscription is being asked to provide a parish hall.
A kitchener donated the sum of $100.
A clergyman has been appointed as assistant minister.
The snow is rapidly disappearing off the summit of the Rockies.
The survey party detailed for the purpose of making a survey through the Kicking Horse Pass, are already located and hard at work.
Messrs. McMillan and Smith have returned from their trip, while Neilson, Weston and Quickborn's parties are working from the other side towards the summit.
It is reported that the Provincial Government telegraphed to Ottawa that the Legislative Council desire a delegation, consisting of three members, to be received, to whom answer was given that the request of the resolution passed by the council would be complied with, and that the delegation would be refused.
The delegation would be met at any time by the Dominion Government.
